title: Synthetic Recap
body:
**Knicks Stun Warriors as Ewing Delivers Historic Masterpiece**

SAN FRANCISCO — In a game that will be remembered not for its final score, but for the sheer force of one man’s will, Patrick Ewing authored a performance for the ages, carrying the New York Knicks to a gritty 105-100 victory over the Golden State Warriors in 1997.

Ewing was not merely the best player on the floor; he was an unstoppable titan, pouring in a career-high and franchise-record 50 points. From the opening tip, the Knicks' offense was a simple, devastating proposition: get the ball to the big man. Ewing operated with ruthless efficiency from the block, hitting fallaway jumpers, powering through double-teams, and commanding the glass with a game-high 17 rebounds.

Despite Ewing’s singular dominance, the Warriors, led by Latrell Sprewell’s 31 points, refused to capitulate. They chipped away at the Knicks' lead throughout the second half, turning the final minutes into a tense battle. Yet, every time Golden State threatened, Ewing had an answer—a crucial bucket, a defensive stop, or a commanding rebound.

The Knicks’ supporting cast played their roles perfectly, feeding the hot hand and providing just enough supplementary scoring from Allan Houston (17 points) to keep the defense honest. But this night belonged unequivocally to their captain. As the final buzzer sounded, the stat sheet told a story of historic proportions: 50 points, a record-breaking feat that cemented Ewing’s legacy in a single, breathtaking evening of basketball brilliance. It was a legendary performance that lifted his team to a hard-fought road win and etched his name even deeper into the lore of the game.
